Pastoretta was the daughter OF plain
country gentleman, whose independent cir.
cumstances enabled him to give her liberal
advantages. She passed through all the
common forms of education. and no expense
was spared to accomplish her mind and per-
son.


But her parents, though kind and indui-
gent, were illiterate. and gave her entirely
into the hands of her teachers, not pretend
ing to dictate in what way she should be
TAUGHT. or how her studies should be arrang-
ed. In the management OF her scieutlhc
pursuits, the too common error prevailed.
Every study calculated to elevate her mind
and abstract her from Standardization, was
enforced upon her as task, to which she
must submit, because such knowledge as 1t
would furnish was fashionable; as rezuard
for accomplishing such tasks, she was al
lowed to read romances. novels, and that
captivating kind of poetry which heats the
imagination, but never mends the heart
She abounded in feeling and in sentiment;
but it was that feeling and that sentiment
which centres in self. 1t was easy and de-
liphtful to recline on bed of roses, and melt
in tender anguish over dying insect; but
carry Pastoretta into sick room where
poverty and sickness are united; bid her
watch dying friend bid her perform those
Offices which the weakness attendant upon
long sickness and confinement require, and
she becomes impatient, her nerves are at
fected, her delicate frame is exhausted, and
every pretencc is laid hold ofthat can ex-
cusc her attendance, OIL free her from care.
Yet had you told Pastoretta she was desti-
tute of sensiblity. she would have thought
you barbarous. She had been indulged in
light reading till her mind was too much en-
ervated to bear the discipline OF reason; and
as soon as she was freed from the restraints
of school, all high pursuits were thrown
by, and she was careful to cherish those de-
iightful emotions only which she found lux
uriantly described by the poet and the nov-
elist When brought down by unprosper-
GUS fortune to the gross realities of life, des-
pair and suicide ensued.


The restraints of parental authority. mild
as it was, early became irksome; and Pasto-
retta determined by marrying to become her
ewn mistress. A husband she was sure,
could not oppose the wishes pf.a wife like
her. She promised herself a lifs of rap
ture, and believed that all distress would
cease when once freed from a Eother's eau
tons and fathers advice, which she eyss
considered as the offspring ofprudcry, pre-:
judce and affection. and treated with open
csntempt by acting in direct opposition.
THE LADIES' FRIEND.

were passed over it. to save the body from
savage dishonor, by thus concealing the
trace Of its interment. Some of Braddock's
affectionate soldiers SO marked the trees near
the spot where he was laid, that the recol-
lection OF those who visited the west many
years after, could point to the exact place
Of his interment, new emphatically termed
Braddock's grave. 1t is close to the north
ern side of the National road, seven miles
east of .Uniontown.


1t had been rumoured for an early period.
that Braddock had been shot by his men,
More recently it has been stated by one who
could not be mistaken, that in the course Of
the battle, Braddock ordered the Provincial
troops to form a column. They, however,
adhered to the Indian mode of firing sever
ally from the shelter Of the trees Brad
dock, in his vexation. rode up to = young
man by the name Of Fawcett. and with his
sword rashly cut him down. Thomas Faw-
cett, a brother of the killed, soon learned his
fate, and watching his opportunity, reyeng-
ed his brothers. blood, by shooting Brad
dock through the body, of which wound he
died. Thomas Fawcett is now or was late
ly, living near Laurel Hill. He is now 81
years of age.'

Gee Of VersaiHcS.


The American Quarterly Review, which
has been issued from the press at Philadcl-
phia, contains an able summary otthe Pre-.
iiminary sketch of the French Revolution
prefxed by Sir Walter Scott, to his forth
coming life Of Napoleon Bonaparte. The
editor of the Review having been permitted,
by the proprietors of that work, to select
for publication some of the most interesting
passages. we take the opportunity to lay
before our readers the account which gift
ed and eloquent historian has given OF the
terrible attack OF the popu!ace on the pail
ace of Versailles, on the 5th of October,
which resulted in the torcible transfer of
the royal family in, but an actual imprison-
ment at, the Thuilleres in Paris. We re-
gret that our limits will not permit US to
publish the whole of this sketch, as it IS
contained in the Review, and which is every
way worthy fits distinguished author. The
most material parts of it, however. are given
below, and will frequently remind the read
er Of kindred description Of similar
scene, by the-same hand, in the admirable
tale of the Heart of Mid Lothian.


After speaking Of the immediate causes
Of this terrible eruption, he goes on to state:
| That OF the 5th October. 1889. was of a
singular description, the insurgents being
chiefly of the female sex. The market wo-
men, Danes aur Hailes, as they are called.
half unsexed by the masculine nature of
their employments. and entirely so by the
ferocity Of their manners, had figured early
in the revolution. With these were allied
and associated most of the worthessiand bar
barous Of their own sex, such disgraceful
specimens of humanity as serve but to shew
in what disgraceful state it may be found
to exist Females Of this description began
to assemble early in the morning, in large
groups. with the cries for "bread," which
so easily ronsed a starving metropolis
fsI'here were observed amongst them many
men disguised as women, and they compeli
ed all the females they met to go along with
them. They marched to the Hotel de Vile,
FRENCH REVOLUTION.

Mine miles above Pittsburg, and immedi-


ately upon the north bank of the Mcnonga-


hcla river is the celebrated battle ground


called 'Braddock's Field 1t is famous for
the destruction of an army intended to cap


ture Fort du Quesne. crush the extending
power of France, and control the Indians on


our western border. Here Washington


fought and Bratdock fell. On this spot so
Frenchmen and $50 Indians nearly destroy
ed the torty-ninth and fiityfirst regiments
of British regulars, though aided by a num-
ber of provincial troops. The battle was
fought on the afternoon IF the 9th of July,
1765. Seventy years have passed away,
and yet the crumbling bones of men and hor-
ses are seen in every field for mile in cir
cult. For many years they were shrouded
by mourning wilderness OF shadowy woods,
but this has yielded to the busy axe, and the
plough, annually driven amongst the sculls
of the slain and the bones Of the brave
Rich harvests wave over the fields fertiiized
by the blood and bodies of a thousand unbu.
ried men. The partridge whistles, and the
reaper sings On the spot where the cries oi
mortal anguish told the dread rcvelry o!
battle. Twas here the wild hoop OF fierce
savages quelled tive rallying cry Of Europe's
warriors. twas here that they drove the
ruthless tomahawk deep in the churshed
skull of the vanquished, and with yelling
joy, tore the scalp from the head of the tee
Bile and the wounded, the dead and the dy-
ing.


The retreating survivors carried theh


wounded general with them until he died.
He was buried about 40 miles from the bat
tie grot,nd, in the centre of the road his ad
vancing army had cut. To prevent the dis
covery Of this, soldiers, horses and wagons,
BRADDOCK'S FIELD.

Tollng with sullen swell:
BY the colours halfmast high
Der the sea hung rnournfully;

Nv the drums dull muff1cd sound.
By the arms that sweep the groud,

peak ye of soldier gone


In his manhood's pride.
By the chantcd psalm that fills,
Reverently, the ancient hills;
Learn that from his harvest done,
Peasants bear brother on


To his last repose.
By the pail Of snowy white.
Through the yew-trees cleaning bright;
BY the garland on the bier,
Weep, a maiden claims tear


Broken is the rose.
Which is.tenderest rite of alli
Buried virgins coronal-

Farewell gun for warrior dead


Hertlsman's funeral hymn'
Tells not each of human woe!
Each of hope and strength brought low
Number each with holy things,
If one Christening thought it brings,


Ere life's day grow dim.

While my bosom the sweet little messenger held,
As the noontide of manhood beamed warm on


my day,
Like the frost work of morning it melted away.
have wept-who has not' and the tear as it fell
Bore with it the sorrow that caused it to swell;

tears,

have err'd-who has mott 'tis the frailty of all,

STANZAS.

She married, at the early and lnexperlehc-
ed age OF fifteen, gentleman of fne per-
son and much good nature, but for whom she
never felt that deep rooted esteem absolute
" essential to happiness in the marriage
state. After she commenced us-keeplng,
and found that something more must De
done, than merely to recline on BEDS OF now
ers, wander by charming rivulets, or waste
the day in reciprocations OF fondness, she De-
came petulent; her mouth was no longer
decked with perpetual dimples; she fretted'
wept and upbraided. Domestic discord soon
produced serious and lasting distress. Her
husband, weak in principle as herself, sought
abroad the pleasure he no longer iounu at
home. Dissipation impaired MS cohstNu"
tion. and wasted his fortune; bankruptcy en-
sued; and the wife, who ought to nave sooth-
ed his sorrow, and by industry and economy
assisted in retrieving his fortune, upbraided
him for reducing one, whose education was
so refined, to a mere household drudge.-
Such united perplexities were too mighty
for his enfeebled constitution, and Pastoret-
ia was left widow at the age OF thirty
She had two fine children, but was destitute
of any means of subsistence. Some able
friend offered her liberal assistance that she
might establish herself in some eligible line
of business, but Pastoretta hao read IN her
favorite authors of men and women who no
bin died rather than receive pecuniary as
sistance, and believing that her exquisite
sensibiity never could support state OF de-
pendence, she obstnately refused all relief,
and suffered her creditors to throw her into
prison, determining there to finish what she
imagined a life of misery, by poison. She
effected her horrid purpose the second day
of her imprisonment, rushing unbdden into
the presence OF her eternal Judge, leaving
her children unprovided for, uneducated,
and to the mercy of'strangers.


Pastoretta is no imaginary character; the
author personally knew her, knew her to be
possessed of fine talents. a lovely person,
and most engaging manners; and had she
been hroheriy educated, she would have
been an ornament to science, and blessing
| to the world.


| 1t will not do to raise the superstructure
of All ediHce before the foundation IS well Sc
cured. A girl who studies little and reads
much, is more exposed to the storms OF rate,
more liable to be raised too high or sunk too
low, than even one who never reads any
thing.
Had Pastorctta's mind been properly reg
ulated and methodizcd by study, had she


been made acquainted with life and manners
as tney really are, IroU buoho WHiSh oiSot"S
the language of truth, however dissonant to
the pride of the human heart; had she been
guided by that wisdom,


"Before whose dear, discerning eye,


The visionary shadows fly,


Offolly's painted show;


Who sees through every fair disguise,


That all, but virtues solid joys,


Is vanity and woe;''


had she been taught that we must live like


christians not sentimentaize with the nov


elist. or expect to be any thing more thar


dependents on heaven and on each other
her fate would have been found supportable
her babes would not have been forsaken, TIN


poison never would have touched her lips.


To prevent girls from reading every nov
, ell extant, is now nearly impossible. But
should be the business of those who instruc
to fortify their minds against the attack
: they invariably make upon virtue by point
: ing out their defects, and by impressing thi
ftruth upon the mind, that they are the OIL


spring Of Inauguration, and afford no picture
of real life, no rules that can guide ther
= through rough and hard-judgng world.

Our female readers, who are disposed to prac-
tice little domestic economy, win find the fol-

cost very little. To 1 pint of alcohol add go
drops OF lavendery, so do. Bergamot, so essence
OF lemon, 81 do. orange water. To gallon of
alcohol put $40 droops of each Of the perfumes.

A man of learning lived upon the banks
of river; he was not one of those amiable
sages who enjoy in solitude the fruits of their
studies, but a real pedant, overflowing with
Greek and Latin, who necessarily torment
ed every body he met, with quotations, met
aphors, &c. If he had but contented him.
self with addressing those who were able to
understand him-sut he was surrounded by
poor peasants, who knew little beyond the
field and plough, and yet he persecuyed even
them into their huts, with Homer, Horace
and Sophocles, without even translating his
quotations. "Sir, said the peasants to him,
let US till our fields, and plant our cabbages;
if we spent our time in filling our heads with :
things which we do not understand, your
cook would find no vegetables in market,
and you wouldnot have such fine fruit up-
on your table," But instead of seeing the
truth of this observation, he exclaimed, with
much self-satisfaction, Labor inhro6us
omnia pincit."


Not far from this pedant lived sailor,
drol fellow, who was always merry and
happy, constantly singing, and was consd-
cred very skilful in his profession. One
day the pedant had occasion to go to the
other side of the river, and went ON board
our sailors boat, who Immediately took his
oars and pushed off. On the way the fol-
lowing dialogue took place between them.
| "Friend," said the passenger to the boat
man, "you seem to be very cheerful and
happy, and l suppose you are very well sat-
isfied with YOURSELF"


"And why should not be satisfied" said
the boatman; Il make good use of my time,
and have no cause for sorrow"


"Ah you make good use OF your time
Truly should be glad to know whether you
deserve to be so happy. Can you readi"


mo sir, not letter."


poor wretch you cannot read, and yet
}you sing Why you have lost quarter of
your life ''


! The boatman did not answer, but contin-
ued to sing. Soon after the pedant continu-


"Can you write." M


"Why, to be sure not I told you could
not read, so how should write"'


"What, you cannot write, and are vet so
cheerful You have lost another quarter of
your life!"


The boatman shrugged his shoulders, but
did not seem less cheerful than before
Presently the pedant began again.


"Boatman, de you understand mineralogy,
ornithology, zoology. astrology, physiology
and psychology, Ssc.'"


THE duce take all your foolish leng
names! What do want with them?"
|
things and yet fancy yourself so happy.--
Why, you have again lost quarter of your
life!'


During this conversation storm had sud-
denly arisen, the waves tossed the light boat,
and at length drove it on the point of rock
on which it could not but perish.


Sir" said the boatmen to his companion,
at this critical moment, "can you swims"


"No, indeed, l cannot; have had more
important matters TO attend to-"
| "Well then fear you have lost your
whole life"


Thus saying, he leaped into the waves,
and swan on shore. He suffered the Pc
dant to struggle awhile in the water, and
pretended not to hear his cries for assist
ance At length he took compassion on
him, helped him out of the water and took
him home half dead with fear. dripping wet,
and trembling with cold. Since that time,
the pcdant is said to have lost most of his
pride.
THE PEDANT AND THE SAILOR.

threats which rcsounded on all sides. hc-
cordingly, a gun was actually lcvelled. but
one of the by-standers struck ii down: for
the passions of the mob had taken an oppo-
site turn, and astonished at Maria Antoin-
ette's noble presence, and graceful firm
ness of demeanour, there arose, almost IN
spite of themselves, general shout ofpiUa
Lc Refine!


But if the insurgents, or rather those who
prompted them. missed their first point,
they did not also lose their second. A cry
arose, s'to Paris'' at first uttered by soli-
tary voice, but gathered strength until the
whole multitude shouted "To Paris-to Par
isl" The cry of these blood-thirsty bacchan-
ais, such as they had that night shown them
selves, was, it seems, considered as the
voice of the people, and as such, Lafayette
neither demonstrated himself, nor permitted
the King to interpose moments delay In
yielding obedience to 1t: nor was any meas
ure taken to put some appearance even OF
decency on the journey, or to disguise its re-
al character, of triumphant procession ct
the sovereign people, after complete vlcto-
ry over their nominal monarch.


The carriages of the royal family were
placed in the middle of an immeasurable
column, consisting partly of Lafayette's SOL
ders, partly of the revolutionary rabble
whose march had preceded his, amounting
to several thousand men and women OF the
lowest and most desperate description, in
termingling in groups amongst the bands of
French Guards, and civic soldiers, whose
discipline could not enable them to preserve
even the semblance of order. Thus they
rushed along, bowling their songs OF triumph,
The barbingers of the march bore the two
bloody heads of the murdered Cardes de
Corhs, paraded on pixies, at the head of the
column, as the emblems oftheir prowess and
success.


The rest of this body, worn down by ia
tigue. most of them despoiled of their arms,
and many without hats, anxious for the tate
of the royal family, and harassed with appre-
tensions for themselves, were dragged ike
captives in the midst of the mob, whlle the
drunken females around them bore aott in
triumph their arms, their belts, and their
bats. These wretches. stained with the
blood in which they had bathed themselves,
were now singing songs, OF which the bur
then bore. nWe bring you the baker, his
wife, and the little apprentices" as it the
presence Of the unhappy royal family. with
the little power they now possessed, had
been in itself charm against scarcity.-
Some of these Amazons rode upon the can
non, which made formidable part of the
procession. Many of'them were mounted
on the horses of the Gardes de Corhs, some
in masculine fashion, others en- cronhe. All
the muskets and pixies that attended this I'M
mense cavalcade, were garnishgd, as IT IN
triumph, with oak boughs, and the women
carried long poplar branches in their hands,
which gave the column, SO grotesqueiy COM
posed in every respect, the appearance OF
grove. Scarce circumstance was omitted


which could render this entrance into the
capital, more insulting to the Kings feelings
more degrading to the royal dignity.
After six hours of dishonor and agony, the
unfortunate Louis was brought to the Hotel


de Vile, where Bailli. then Mayor, compi-


mented him upon the '6eauJoar,' the 'splen-
did day. which restored the monarch OF
France to his capital; assured him that Or


der, peace, and all the gentler virtues. we're
about to revive in't the country under his roy


al eye, and that the King would henceforth


become powerful through the people, the


people happy through the king;- land what


was the truest of ALL" that as Henry ~


had entered Paris by means of re-conquer-
ing his people, so Louis XVI. had done so,
because his people had re-cenquered their
King. His wounds salved with this llp-com-
fort, the unhappy aud degraded prince was
: at length permitted to retire to the palace oil
the Tuilleres, which long inhabited, and
almost unturnished. yawned upon him like
the tomb, where alone he at length found re-
pose.

Friends are all very true when nothing is re-
qnired ofthemb beyond friendship; but when You
rely on them. they bend, md i'll brook support
ing.


Adversely is like the period Of tic former and
Of the latter rains-cold, cornfortless, unfriendiy
to man and to animal, yet from thence come the
flower and the fruit, the date. the rose, and
pomea arAnate. = eFlk = Nfa.

broke boldly through the National Guard.


who wei re drawn up in front OF that building
for it's defence, and were with difficulty dis
suaded from burning the records 1t contain
ed. They next seized magazine OF arms.
with three or four pieces OF cannon, and
were joined by a miscellaneous rabble, arm
ed with pixies, scythes and similar instru-
ments, who called themselves the conquer
ors of the Bastile. The still increasing null
titude re-echoed the cry of "Bread, bread
to Versailles to VersaiHes!'


! The National Guard we're now called out
in force, but speedily showed their officers
that they too were infected with the humor
of the times, and as much ndisposed to sub
ordination as the mob, to dsperse which they
were summoned. Lafayette put himself at
their head not to give his own but to re-
| ccive their orders. They refused to act a.
gainst women, who they said were starving,
and in their turn demanded to be led to Yer
sailles. to dethrone-such was their language
1.-THE King, who was driveller. and place
the crown on the head of his son." Latay-
cite hestated, implored, explained but he
had as yet to learn the situation OF revolu-
tionary General. '1s it not STRANGE" said
one of his soldiers, who seemed quite to un-
derstand the military relation OF ofhcer and
private ON such an OCCASION rs 1t not strange
that Lafayette pretends to command the peo'
Pile, when it is his part to receive orders
| from them? ?"


Soon afterwards. an order arrived from
the Assembly of the Commune OF Paris, en-
Joining the commandments march, upon his
own report that it was impossible to with
stand the will of the people. He marched
accordingly in good order, and at the head
of large body of the National Guard, a
bout four or five hours after the departure
of the mob, who while he waited in a state
Of indecision, were already far on their way
! to Versailles.


It does not appear that the King or his
ministers had any intimation Of these hostile
movements. Assuredly there could have
been no royalist in Paris willing to hazard a
horse or a groom to carry such intelligence
where the knowledge of it must have been
SO important. The leading members of the
Assembly assembled at Versailles, were bet
ter informed. "These gentlemen" said
Barbantanne, looking at the part of the hall


where the clergy usually sat, "wish more


light--thcy shall have lanterns, they may


rely upon it." Mirabeau went behind the
chair of Mounier the president. "Paris is


marching upon u.s." said he" know not


what you mcan," said Mounier. "Believe


me or not, Paris is marching upon us--ds-


solye.thc. sitting" never hurry the dclibe-


rations. said Mounier.--"Then fain illness"


said Mirabcau, "go to the palace-tell


them what l say, and give me for authority.
but there is not a minute to lose-Paris


marches upon us" $50 much the better"


answered Mounier, 1--WE will be Republi;


the sooner" Mounier must be supposed to


speak ironically, and in allusion, not to his
own, but to Mirabeau's S revolutionary tenets.
Another account of this singular conversa-
, tion states his answer to have been, "All the
better. IF the mob kill all of us--remark,
. ! say all of us-it will be the better for the
: country"


1t was now night, and the armed rabb|c
Of both sexes Showed no intention of depart
t ing or breaking up. On the contrary, they
I bivouacked, after their own manner, upoi
the parade, where the soldiers usually mus
tered. There they kindled large fires, ate
drank, sang, caroused, and occasionally dis
charged their firearms. Scufiles arose from
time to time, one or two of the Garges al
n Co7Hs had been killed and wounded in the


quarrel, which the rioters had endeavouret


to fasten on them; besides which this de-


voted corps had sustained a voley from


their late guests, the National Guard o
/ Versailles. The horse of Cards de Corp


which fell into the hands Of these female de
!, mons, was tern in pieces, and eaten halfrav
I and half roasted. Every thing seemed tend
). ing to a general engagement, when late a
) night the drums announced The approach


of General Lafayette, at the head OF his civ
2 c army, which moved slowly but in good or
!, der.


1 A band of the rioters found means to pen
r citrate into the palace about three in th
Y morning, through gate that was left un
! locked and unguarded. They rushed to tn
e Queens apartment and bore down the few
J. Cards de CorhS who hastened to her de
r. fence. The sentinel knocked at the door O
# her bedchamber, and then gallantly expose'
l. himself to the fury of the murderers Hi
= single opposition was almost instantly over
% come, and he himself left for dead. Owe
is his bleeding body they forced their way int
" the Queens apartment; but their victim, re
e served for farther and worse woes, had es
n capped by secret passage into the chambe
J. of the king, while the assassins. bursting in
IT stabbed the bed she had just left with pike
e and swords.


The outside Of the palace was still besieg
IS ed by the infuriated mob, who demanded
G: with hideous CRIES and exclamations tn
a most barbarous and obscene, to see the Aus
g trian, as they called the Queen. The'unfor
D. tunate Princess appeared on the balcony
i, with one of her children in each hand.

full articles.headline: THE LADIES' FRIEND.
full articles.article:
Pastoretta was the daughter OF plain
country gentleman, whose independent cir.
cumstances enabled him to give her liberal
advantages. She passed through all the
common forms of education. and no expense
was spared to accomplish her mind and per-
son.


But her parents, though kind and indui-
gent, were illiterate. and gave her entirely
into the hands of her teachers, not pretend
ing to dictate in what way she should be
TAUGHT. or how her studies should be arrang-
ed. In the management OF her scieutlhc
pursuits, the too common error prevailed.
Every study calculated to elevate her mind
and abstract her from Standardization, was
enforced upon her as task, to which she
must submit, because such knowledge as 1t
would furnish was fashionable; as rezuard
for accomplishing such tasks, she was al
lowed to read romances. novels, and that
captivating kind of poetry which heats the
imagination, but never mends the heart
She abounded in feeling and in sentiment;
but it was that feeling and that sentiment
which centres in self. 1t was easy and de-
liphtful to recline on bed of roses, and melt
in tender anguish over dying insect; but
carry Pastoretta into sick room where
poverty and sickness are united; bid her
watch dying friend bid her perform those
Offices which the weakness attendant upon
long sickness and confinement require, and
she becomes impatient, her nerves are at
fected, her delicate frame is exhausted, and
every pretencc is laid hold ofthat can ex-
cusc her attendance, OIL free her from care.
Yet had you told Pastoretta she was desti-
tute of sensiblity. she would have thought
you barbarous. She had been indulged in
light reading till her mind was too much en-
ervated to bear the discipline OF reason; and
as soon as she was freed from the restraints
of school, all high pursuits were thrown
by, and she was careful to cherish those de-
iightful emotions only which she found lux
uriantly described by the poet and the nov-
elist When brought down by unprosper-
GUS fortune to the gross realities of life, des-
pair and suicide ensued.


The restraints of parental authority. mild
as it was, early became irksome; and Pasto-
retta determined by marrying to become her
ewn mistress. A husband she was sure,
could not oppose the wishes pf.a wife like
her. She promised herself a lifs of rap
ture, and believed that all distress would
cease when once freed from a Eother's eau
tons and fathers advice, which she eyss
considered as the offspring ofprudcry, pre-:
judce and affection. and treated with open
csntempt by acting in direct opposition.

were passed over it. to save the body from
savage dishonor, by thus concealing the
trace Of its interment. Some of Braddock's
affectionate soldiers SO marked the trees near
the spot where he was laid, that the recol-
lection OF those who visited the west many
years after, could point to the exact place
Of his interment, new emphatically termed
Braddock's grave. 1t is close to the north
ern side of the National road, seven miles
east of .Uniontown.


1t had been rumoured for an early period.
that Braddock had been shot by his men,
More recently it has been stated by one who
could not be mistaken, that in the course Of
the battle, Braddock ordered the Provincial
troops to form a column. They, however,
adhered to the Indian mode of firing sever
ally from the shelter Of the trees Brad
dock, in his vexation. rode up to = young
man by the name Of Fawcett. and with his
sword rashly cut him down. Thomas Faw-
cett, a brother of the killed, soon learned his
fate, and watching his opportunity, reyeng-
ed his brothers. blood, by shooting Brad
dock through the body, of which wound he
died. Thomas Fawcett is now or was late
ly, living near Laurel Hill. He is now 81
years of age.'

full articles.headline: FRENCH REVOLUTION.
full articles.article:
l1Sufectt0U OJ Re olH Cch1OeT-.ItIuch oH fHc ut-


Gee Of VersaiHcS.


The American Quarterly Review, which
has been issued from the press at Philadcl-
phia, contains an able summary otthe Pre-.
iiminary sketch of the French Revolution
prefxed by Sir Walter Scott, to his forth
coming life Of Napoleon Bonaparte. The
editor of the Review having been permitted,
by the proprietors of that work, to select
for publication some of the most interesting
passages. we take the opportunity to lay
before our readers the account which gift
ed and eloquent historian has given OF the
terrible attack OF the popu!ace on the pail
ace of Versailles, on the 5th of October,
which resulted in the torcible transfer of
the royal family in, but an actual imprison-
ment at, the Thuilleres in Paris. We re-
gret that our limits will not permit US to
publish the whole of this sketch, as it IS
contained in the Review, and which is every
way worthy fits distinguished author. The
most material parts of it, however. are given
below, and will frequently remind the read
er Of kindred description Of similar
scene, by the-same hand, in the admirable
tale of the Heart of Mid Lothian.


After speaking Of the immediate causes
Of this terrible eruption, he goes on to state:
| That OF the 5th October. 1889. was of a
singular description, the insurgents being
chiefly of the female sex. The market wo-
men, Danes aur Hailes, as they are called.
half unsexed by the masculine nature of
their employments. and entirely so by the
ferocity Of their manners, had figured early
in the revolution. With these were allied
and associated most of the worthessiand bar
barous Of their own sex, such disgraceful
specimens of humanity as serve but to shew
in what disgraceful state it may be found
to exist Females Of this description began
to assemble early in the morning, in large
groups. with the cries for "bread," which
so easily ronsed a starving metropolis
fsI'here were observed amongst them many
men disguised as women, and they compeli
ed all the females they met to go along with
them. They marched to the Hotel de Vile,
full articles.byline:
Instruction oftke 5M Octojer-.attach on the Pal


Gee Of Versaihcs.

full articles.headline: BRADDOCK'S FIELD.
full articles.article:
Mine miles above Pittsburg, and immedi-


ately upon the north bank of the Mcnonga-


hcla river is the celebrated battle ground


called 'Braddock's Field 1t is famous for
the destruction of an army intended to cap


ture Fort du Quesne. crush the extending
power of France, and control the Indians on


our western border. Here Washington


fought and Bratdock fell. On this spot so
Frenchmen and $50 Indians nearly destroy
ed the torty-ninth and fiityfirst regiments
of British regulars, though aided by a num-
ber of provincial troops. The battle was
fought on the afternoon IF the 9th of July,
1765. Seventy years have passed away,
and yet the crumbling bones of men and hor-
ses are seen in every field for mile in cir
cult. For many years they were shrouded
by mourning wilderness OF shadowy woods,
but this has yielded to the busy axe, and the
plough, annually driven amongst the sculls
of the slain and the bones Of the brave
Rich harvests wave over the fields fertiiized
by the blood and bodies of a thousand unbu.
ried men. The partridge whistles, and the
reaper sings On the spot where the cries oi
mortal anguish told the dread rcvelry o!
battle. Twas here the wild hoop OF fierce
savages quelled tive rallying cry Of Europe's
warriors. twas here that they drove the
ruthless tomahawk deep in the churshed
skull of the vanquished, and with yelling
joy, tore the scalp from the head of the tee
Bile and the wounded, the dead and the dy-
ing.


The retreating survivors carried theh


wounded general with them until he died.
He was buried about 40 miles from the bat
tie grot,nd, in the centre of the road his ad
vancing army had cut. To prevent the dis
covery Of this, soldiers, horses and wagons,

full articles.headline: .5,pQla7rIsYs
full articles.article:
LAST RITZ ny Ms. Rerans.
By the mighty Minstre's bell,
Tollng with sullen swell:
BY the colours halfmast high
Der the sea hung rnournfully;
Know Prince hath died.
Nv the drums dull muff1cd sound.
By the arms that sweep the groud,
By the volleying musket's tore,
peak ye of soldier gone


In his manhood's pride.
By the chantcd psalm that fills,
Reverently, the ancient hills;
Learn that from his harvest done,
Peasants bear brother on


To his last repose.
By the pail Of snowy white.
Through the yew-trees cleaning bright;
BY the garland on the bier,
Weep, a maiden claims tear


Broken is the rose.
Which is.tenderest rite of alli
Buried virgins coronal-
REQUIEM DER the monarch's head
Farewell gun for warrior dead


Hertlsman's funeral hymn'
Tells not each of human woe!
Each of hope and strength brought low
Number each with holy things,
If one Christening thought it brings,


Ere life's day grow dim.

full articles.headline: STANZAS.
full articles.article:
lhave loved-who has not' and the charm was


dispell'd,
While my bosom the sweet little messenger held,
As the noontide of manhood beamed warm on


my day,
Like the frost work of morning it melted away.
have wept-who has not' and the tear as it fell
Bore with it the sorrow that caused it to swell;
Even grief was dissolved in the warm tide OF


tears,
And remembrance was lost in the current OF


years.


have err'd-who has mott 'tis the frailty of all,
And to grieve when too late, with sour face to


the wall;''


But the wild song of folly rose high on the wind,
And the feeling was lost in the riot of mind.
I have bowed-who has not' to the Beng a


bove,


Whose attribute mercy, is given in lore;
Nor folly, nor manhood, nor years as they roll,
Can efface the best feeling tEAt clngs to my soul

She married, at the early and lnexperlehc-
ed age OF fifteen, gentleman of fne per-
son and much good nature, but for whom she
never felt that deep rooted esteem absolute
" essential to happiness in the marriage
state. After she commenced us-keeplng,
and found that something more must De
done, than merely to recline on BEDS OF now
ers, wander by charming rivulets, or waste
the day in reciprocations OF fondness, she De-
came petulent; her mouth was no longer
decked with perpetual dimples; she fretted'
wept and upbraided. Domestic discord soon
produced serious and lasting distress. Her
husband, weak in principle as herself, sought
abroad the pleasure he no longer iounu at
home. Dissipation impaired MS cohstNu"
tion. and wasted his fortune; bankruptcy en-
sued; and the wife, who ought to nave sooth-
ed his sorrow, and by industry and economy
assisted in retrieving his fortune, upbraided
him for reducing one, whose education was
so refined, to a mere household drudge.-
Such united perplexities were too mighty
for his enfeebled constitution, and Pastoret-
ia was left widow at the age OF thirty
She had two fine children, but was destitute
of any means of subsistence. Some able
friend offered her liberal assistance that she
might establish herself in some eligible line
of business, but Pastoretta hao read IN her
favorite authors of men and women who no
bin died rather than receive pecuniary as
sistance, and believing that her exquisite
sensibiity never could support state OF de-
pendence, she obstnately refused all relief,
and suffered her creditors to throw her into
prison, determining there to finish what she
imagined a life of misery, by poison. She
effected her horrid purpose the second day
of her imprisonment, rushing unbdden into
the presence OF her eternal Judge, leaving
her children unprovided for, uneducated,
and to the mercy of'strangers.


Pastoretta is no imaginary character; the
author personally knew her, knew her to be
possessed of fine talents. a lovely person,
and most engaging manners; and had she
been hroheriy educated, she would have
been an ornament to science, and blessing
| to the world.


| 1t will not do to raise the superstructure
of All ediHce before the foundation IS well Sc
cured. A girl who studies little and reads
much, is more exposed to the storms OF rate,
more liable to be raised too high or sunk too
low, than even one who never reads any
thing.
Had Pastorctta's mind been properly reg
ulated and methodizcd by study, had she


been made acquainted with life and manners
as tney really are, IroU buoho WHiSh oiSot"S
the language of truth, however dissonant to
the pride of the human heart; had she been
guided by that wisdom,


"Before whose dear, discerning eye,


The visionary shadows fly,


Offolly's painted show;


Who sees through every fair disguise,


That all, but virtues solid joys,


Is vanity and woe;''


had she been taught that we must live like


christians not sentimentaize with the nov


elist. or expect to be any thing more thar


dependents on heaven and on each other
her fate would have been found supportable
her babes would not have been forsaken, TIN


poison never would have touched her lips.


To prevent girls from reading every nov
, ell extant, is now nearly impossible. But
should be the business of those who instruc
to fortify their minds against the attack
: they invariably make upon virtue by point
: ing out their defects, and by impressing thi
ftruth upon the mind, that they are the OIL


spring Of Inauguration, and afford no picture
of real life, no rules that can guide ther
= through rough and hard-judgng world.

full articles.headline: COLOGNE WATER.
full articles.article:
Our female readers, who are disposed to prac-
tice little domestic economy, win find the fol-
lowing preparation of Cologne Water, a very
cheap substitute for the Cologne Water of the
shops, for which they pay three or four hundred
per cent more than the cost of this. The prin-
cipal ingredient is only worth one dollar per gal
lon at retail by the druggists, and the perfumcry
cost very little. To 1 pint of alcohol add go
drops OF lavendery, so do. Bergamot, so essence
OF lemon, 81 do. orange water. To gallon of
alcohol put $40 droops of each Of the perfumes.

full articles.headline: THE PEDANT AND THE SAILOR.
full articles.article:
A man of learning lived upon the banks
of river; he was not one of those amiable
sages who enjoy in solitude the fruits of their
studies, but a real pedant, overflowing with
Greek and Latin, who necessarily torment
ed every body he met, with quotations, met
aphors, &c. If he had but contented him.
self with addressing those who were able to
understand him-sut he was surrounded by
poor peasants, who knew little beyond the
field and plough, and yet he persecuyed even
them into their huts, with Homer, Horace
and Sophocles, without even translating his
quotations. "Sir, said the peasants to him,
let US till our fields, and plant our cabbages;
if we spent our time in filling our heads with :
things which we do not understand, your
cook would find no vegetables in market,
and you wouldnot have such fine fruit up-
on your table," But instead of seeing the
truth of this observation, he exclaimed, with
much self-satisfaction, Labor inhro6us
omnia pincit."


Not far from this pedant lived sailor,
drol fellow, who was always merry and
happy, constantly singing, and was consd-
cred very skilful in his profession. One
day the pedant had occasion to go to the
other side of the river, and went ON board
our sailors boat, who Immediately took his
oars and pushed off. On the way the fol-
lowing dialogue took place between them.
| "Friend," said the passenger to the boat
man, "you seem to be very cheerful and
happy, and l suppose you are very well sat-
isfied with YOURSELF"


"And why should not be satisfied" said
the boatman; Il make good use of my time,
and have no cause for sorrow"


"Ah you make good use OF your time
Truly should be glad to know whether you
deserve to be so happy. Can you readi"


mo sir, not letter."


poor wretch you cannot read, and yet
}you sing Why you have lost quarter of
your life ''


! The boatman did not answer, but contin-
ued to sing. Soon after the pedant continu-


"Can you write." M


"Why, to be sure not I told you could
not read, so how should write"'


"What, you cannot write, and are vet so
cheerful You have lost another quarter of
your life!"


The boatman shrugged his shoulders, but
did not seem less cheerful than before
Presently the pedant began again.


"Boatman, de you understand mineralogy,
ornithology, zoology. astrology, physiology
and psychology, Ssc.'"


THE duce take all your foolish leng
names! What do want with them?"
|
things and yet fancy yourself so happy.--
Why, you have again lost quarter of your
life!'


During this conversation storm had sud-
denly arisen, the waves tossed the light boat,
and at length drove it on the point of rock
on which it could not but perish.


Sir" said the boatmen to his companion,
at this critical moment, "can you swims"


"No, indeed, l cannot; have had more
important matters TO attend to-"
| "Well then fear you have lost your
whole life"


Thus saying, he leaped into the waves,
and swan on shore. He suffered the Pc
dant to struggle awhile in the water, and
pretended not to hear his cries for assist
ance At length he took compassion on
him, helped him out of the water and took
him home half dead with fear. dripping wet,
and trembling with cold. Since that time,
the pcdant is said to have lost most of his
pride.

threats which rcsounded on all sides. hc-
cordingly, a gun was actually lcvelled. but
one of the by-standers struck ii down: for
the passions of the mob had taken an oppo-
site turn, and astonished at Maria Antoin-
ette's noble presence, and graceful firm
ness of demeanour, there arose, almost IN
spite of themselves, general shout ofpiUa
Lc Refine!


But if the insurgents, or rather those who
prompted them. missed their first point,
they did not also lose their second. A cry
arose, s'to Paris'' at first uttered by soli-
tary voice, but gathered strength until the
whole multitude shouted "To Paris-to Par
isl" The cry of these blood-thirsty bacchan-
ais, such as they had that night shown them
selves, was, it seems, considered as the
voice of the people, and as such, Lafayette
neither demonstrated himself, nor permitted
the King to interpose moments delay In
yielding obedience to 1t: nor was any meas
ure taken to put some appearance even OF
decency on the journey, or to disguise its re-
al character, of triumphant procession ct
the sovereign people, after complete vlcto-
ry over their nominal monarch.


The carriages of the royal family were
placed in the middle of an immeasurable
column, consisting partly of Lafayette's SOL
ders, partly of the revolutionary rabble
whose march had preceded his, amounting
to several thousand men and women OF the
lowest and most desperate description, in
termingling in groups amongst the bands of
French Guards, and civic soldiers, whose
discipline could not enable them to preserve
even the semblance of order. Thus they
rushed along, bowling their songs OF triumph,
The barbingers of the march bore the two
bloody heads of the murdered Cardes de
Corhs, paraded on pixies, at the head of the
column, as the emblems oftheir prowess and
success.


The rest of this body, worn down by ia
tigue. most of them despoiled of their arms,
and many without hats, anxious for the tate
of the royal family, and harassed with appre-
tensions for themselves, were dragged ike
captives in the midst of the mob, whlle the
drunken females around them bore aott in
triumph their arms, their belts, and their
bats. These wretches. stained with the
blood in which they had bathed themselves,
were now singing songs, OF which the bur
then bore. nWe bring you the baker, his
wife, and the little apprentices" as it the
presence Of the unhappy royal family. with
the little power they now possessed, had
been in itself charm against scarcity.-
Some of these Amazons rode upon the can
non, which made formidable part of the
procession. Many of'them were mounted
on the horses of the Gardes de Corhs, some
in masculine fashion, others en- cronhe. All
the muskets and pixies that attended this I'M
mense cavalcade, were garnishgd, as IT IN
triumph, with oak boughs, and the women
carried long poplar branches in their hands,
which gave the column, SO grotesqueiy COM
posed in every respect, the appearance OF
grove. Scarce circumstance was omitted


which could render this entrance into the
capital, more insulting to the Kings feelings
more degrading to the royal dignity.
After six hours of dishonor and agony, the
unfortunate Louis was brought to the Hotel


de Vile, where Bailli. then Mayor, compi-


mented him upon the '6eauJoar,' the 'splen-
did day. which restored the monarch OF
France to his capital; assured him that Or


der, peace, and all the gentler virtues. we're
about to revive in't the country under his roy


al eye, and that the King would henceforth


become powerful through the people, the


people happy through the king;- land what


was the truest of ALL" that as Henry ~


had entered Paris by means of re-conquer-
ing his people, so Louis XVI. had done so,
because his people had re-cenquered their
King. His wounds salved with this llp-com-
fort, the unhappy aud degraded prince was
: at length permitted to retire to the palace oil
the Tuilleres, which long inhabited, and
almost unturnished. yawned upon him like
the tomb, where alone he at length found re-
pose.

Friends are all very true when nothing is re-
qnired ofthemb beyond friendship; but when You
rely on them. they bend, md i'll brook support
ing.


Adversely is like the period Of tic former and
Of the latter rains-cold, cornfortless, unfriendiy
to man and to animal, yet from thence come the
flower and the fruit, the date. the rose, and
pomea arAnate. = eFlk = Nfa.

broke boldly through the National Guard.


who wei re drawn up in front OF that building
for it's defence, and were with difficulty dis
suaded from burning the records 1t contain
ed. They next seized magazine OF arms.
with three or four pieces OF cannon, and
were joined by a miscellaneous rabble, arm
ed with pixies, scythes and similar instru-
ments, who called themselves the conquer
ors of the Bastile. The still increasing null
titude re-echoed the cry of "Bread, bread
to Versailles to VersaiHes!'


! The National Guard we're now called out
in force, but speedily showed their officers
that they too were infected with the humor
of the times, and as much ndisposed to sub
ordination as the mob, to dsperse which they
were summoned. Lafayette put himself at
their head not to give his own but to re-
| ccive their orders. They refused to act a.
gainst women, who they said were starving,
and in their turn demanded to be led to Yer
sailles. to dethrone-such was their language
1.-THE King, who was driveller. and place
the crown on the head of his son." Latay-
cite hestated, implored, explained but he
had as yet to learn the situation OF revolu-
tionary General. '1s it not STRANGE" said
one of his soldiers, who seemed quite to un-
derstand the military relation OF ofhcer and
private ON such an OCCASION rs 1t not strange
that Lafayette pretends to command the peo'
Pile, when it is his part to receive orders
| from them? ?"


Soon afterwards. an order arrived from
the Assembly of the Commune OF Paris, en-
Joining the commandments march, upon his
own report that it was impossible to with
stand the will of the people. He marched
accordingly in good order, and at the head
of large body of the National Guard, a
bout four or five hours after the departure
of the mob, who while he waited in a state
Of indecision, were already far on their way
! to Versailles.


It does not appear that the King or his
ministers had any intimation Of these hostile
movements. Assuredly there could have
been no royalist in Paris willing to hazard a
horse or a groom to carry such intelligence
where the knowledge of it must have been
SO important. The leading members of the
Assembly assembled at Versailles, were bet
ter informed. "These gentlemen" said
Barbantanne, looking at the part of the hall


where the clergy usually sat, "wish more


light--thcy shall have lanterns, they may


rely upon it." Mirabeau went behind the
chair of Mounier the president. "Paris is


marching upon u.s." said he" know not


what you mcan," said Mounier. "Believe


me or not, Paris is marching upon us--ds-


solye.thc. sitting" never hurry the dclibe-


rations. said Mounier.--"Then fain illness"


said Mirabcau, "go to the palace-tell


them what l say, and give me for authority.
but there is not a minute to lose-Paris


marches upon us" $50 much the better"


answered Mounier, 1--WE will be Republi;


the sooner" Mounier must be supposed to


speak ironically, and in allusion, not to his
own, but to Mirabeau's S revolutionary tenets.
Another account of this singular conversa-
, tion states his answer to have been, "All the
better. IF the mob kill all of us--remark,
. ! say all of us-it will be the better for the
: country"


1t was now night, and the armed rabb|c
Of both sexes Showed no intention of depart
t ing or breaking up. On the contrary, they
I bivouacked, after their own manner, upoi
the parade, where the soldiers usually mus
tered. There they kindled large fires, ate
drank, sang, caroused, and occasionally dis
charged their firearms. Scufiles arose from
time to time, one or two of the Garges al
n Co7Hs had been killed and wounded in the


quarrel, which the rioters had endeavouret


to fasten on them; besides which this de-


voted corps had sustained a voley from


their late guests, the National Guard o
/ Versailles. The horse of Cards de Corp


which fell into the hands Of these female de
!, mons, was tern in pieces, and eaten halfrav
I and half roasted. Every thing seemed tend
). ing to a general engagement, when late a
) night the drums announced The approach


of General Lafayette, at the head OF his civ
2 c army, which moved slowly but in good or
!, der.


1 A band of the rioters found means to pen
r citrate into the palace about three in th
Y morning, through gate that was left un
! locked and unguarded. They rushed to tn
e Queens apartment and bore down the few
J. Cards de CorhS who hastened to her de
r. fence. The sentinel knocked at the door O
# her bedchamber, and then gallantly expose'
l. himself to the fury of the murderers Hi
= single opposition was almost instantly over
% come, and he himself left for dead. Owe
is his bleeding body they forced their way int
" the Queens apartment; but their victim, re
e served for farther and worse woes, had es
n capped by secret passage into the chambe
J. of the king, while the assassins. bursting in
IT stabbed the bed she had just left with pike
e and swords.


The outside Of the palace was still besieg
IS ed by the infuriated mob, who demanded
G: with hideous CRIES and exclamations tn
a most barbarous and obscene, to see the Aus
g trian, as they called the Queen. The'unfor
D. tunate Princess appeared on the balcony
i, with one of her children in each hand.
